awd_abstract_narration:
Title: CAREER: Superchiral Light-Matter Interactions: Plasmonic Devices for Enhanced Structural Biology Characterization

Abstract
Non-Technical:  The human hand is perhaps the best example of a chiral object. Chiral objects cannot be overlaid on their mirror image and are fundamental to life itself. For example, amino acids are left handed and sugars are right handed. Light can also be chiral having either a left- or right-handed twist. Twisted light can interact or "shake hands" with chiral matter offering a rapid, non-invasive method for characterizing the structure of biomolecules. The first goal of this project is to advance the understanding of chiral light-matter interactions, enabling devices that can rapidly identify Parkinson's and Alzheimer's diseases and advance the search for cures. The second goal of this project is to engage 3rd grade and high school students in science and engineering research through videos and mini-courses related to polarized light. Beyond these efforts, this project will directly benefit graduate and undergraduate researchers through mentoring; and more broadly, K-12 students with interests in polarized light-matter interactions.

Technical: Chiral objects, i.e. not superimposable on their mirror image, exhibit optical activity which manifest in circular birefringence and circular dichroism i.e., the difference in the refractive indices and absorption for left and right circularly polarized light (CPL), respectively. Structural biologist have long pursued these chiral light-matter interactions to understand the structure-function relationship in proteins. Unfortunately, traditional optical characterization methods provide low-resolution structural information primarily due to the large size mismatch between biomolecules and the wavelength of light. Nanostructured plasmonic devices can generate superchiral near-fields, which provide highly twisted light i.e., over 100 times that of CPL, confined in sub-diffraction limited volumes. Through this program, the PI will investigate superchiral light-matter interactions between fabricated plasmonic devices and biomolecules. This research will explore the energy and spatial overlap between plasmonic resonances and biomolecules in an effort to maximize the enhancement of the far-field chiroptical spectra of the biomolecule. These studies are expected to expand our understanding of superchiral light-matter interactions and lead to a new class of plasmonic devices including those used in early detection of degenerative diseases and drug design for their treatments.

por.por_cntn:
Researchers have employed many nano-optics approaches to amplify the weak effects of natural optical activity ─ circular dichroism (CD) and birefringence (CB). Nanostructures can create electromagnetic near-fields with optical chirality density higher than circularly polarized light (CPL), thus increasing the CD from chiral molecules in these locations. Most chiral analytes of interest (such as biomolecules) have absorption bands in the ultraviolet (UV). Unfortunately, current nanostructures provide enhanced optical chiral densities in the visible or near-infrared regime, creating a large energy mismatch between the metasurface and the chiral analyte. This energy mismatch limits the potential enhancement of weak optical activity from biomolecules.

This project investigated the resonant optical response in the far-ultraviolet (180 nm – 250 nm) between chiral metasurfaces and biomolecules. The far-ultraviolet regime was targeted because most biomolecules, i.e., proteins, peptides, amino acids, etc., exhibit CD in this spectral regime. We found that resonant chiroptical interactions between a plasmonic metasurface and ultrathin (sub 10 nm) biomolecular films were required to enhance the biomolecule's weak natural optical activity signal. Furthermore, contrary to current thinking in the field, the strong chiroptical activity from the metasurface did not obfuscate the weak chiroptical signal from the biomolecule. On the contrary, we found that the weak chiroptical signal from the biomolecule perturbed the strong plasmonic chiroptical response with enantiomeric selectivity. This ultimately allowed us to use plasmonic metasurface to amplify the weak natural optical activity from 9 nm amino acid films above the noise threshold of our instrument and discern their handedness.

We realized metasurface with both near- and far-field chiroptical response in the far-ultraviolet by moving away from traditional plasmonic materials, e.g., Au and Ag, and employing aluminum. Aluminum is arguably the best plasmonic material for ultraviolet applications. We fabricated arrays of aluminum gammadions on fused quartz substrates, which provided strong optical activity in transmission with resonance in the far-ultraviolet and visible regimes. Computational modeling of these metasurfaces also revealed enhanced near-field optical chirality densities in the far-ultraviolet, overlapping with natural optical activity. The energetic position of the near- and far-field chiroptical effects was tuned by changing the lattice pitch, arm width and thickness of the gammadions. Our modeling results supported our experimental findings that resonant interaction between the plasmonic and biomolecular optical activity was required to amplify the weak natural optical activity signal.

To our knowledge, we are the first to report resonant chiroptical plasmonic-biomolecular interactions in the far-ultraviolet regime. Given that most biomolecules of interest are optically active in the far-ultraviolet and not in the visible or near-infrared regimes, we expect our findings to lead to the development of aluminum-based chiroptical metasurfaces with even stronger far-ultraviolet resonances. These future metasurfaces are expected to broadly impact biomedicine, enabling ultrasensitive detection of protein misfolding and enhanced drug discovery. Furthermore, the PI developed and deployed a 30-minute interactive classroom activity to over 400 5th graders for synergistic outreach. This activity introduced grade school-age students to concepts of waves, polarization, and geometric chirality.  In addition, the PI had two to three high school interns working in his laboratory each summer to support the research efforts.
